title: Will a trilateral meeting take place between Chinese President Xi Jinping, Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, and South Korean President Park Geun-hye before 1 January 2016?
preds: It is New Year's Eve and a holiday in Asia, so a major political meeting will not be taking place this year, but maybe next year!
New to this site and getting a bunch of prediction in during the last 24 hours before closing.
Not such a meeting planned yet.
I could find no mention of such a meeting in the news or internet before the end of this year.
they don't have time for this
Moving down to zero for passing of time
China was represented by someone else at this meeting this year.
Considering the tension between China and Japan over the island expansion in the South China Sea, the odds of a meeting are zero.
Once Li subbed for Xi, this question was over, over, over. Affirming prior forecast.
Revising down my prediction as the deadline is approaching
100% it will happen trust on me
Trilateral yes, but the meeting had Si, not Xi. Affirming prior prediction.

1% because hey, pigs might fly outa my...
Not much time left in the year.

The trilateral meeting this question asks about basically took place on the first of november - so the cited reports for a potential meeting in the fall of 2015 were correct. This was a huge step forward in regard to their relations. However, since only Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan and President Park Geun-hye of South Korea were at the meeting, while China was represented by Prime Minister Li Keqiang (and NOT the Chinese President Xi Jinping), this question remains unresolved. There are no plausible indicators for a second meeting in such a short period of time - and time is runnig out: 0%.
No news and we enter a slow period for international meetings.
There is no need for this trilateral meeting since lower level talks were hel ear;ier
Adjusting downward 5% to catch up with the news.
Sorry, didn't realize the question required Chinese President Xi Jinping to attend.  Chinese Premier Li Keqiang attended November 1.  No other meetings are scheduled until next year at the earliest.

Didn't this happen on November 1?  http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2015-11/18/c_134830635.htm  "The trilateral cooperation mechanism consisting of China, Japan and South Korea was restored on Nov. 1 with the resumption of the leaders' meeting after a three-and-a-half-year hiatus due to heightened regional tensions."

Newbie forecasters, this question is a gimme. There was a trilateral meeting last weekend, bu Li stood in for Xi. Likelihood of a new trilateral meeting before the end of the year should be zero, as these events take much planning and a good reason to update the most recent one.
I believe that the meeting recently held satisfies the short term needs of the three countries

very tricky question, as a trilateral meeting did occur, but Jinping wasn't there, but rather Chinese Premier Li Keqiang was instead.  Abe and Guen-hye were there.  http://thediplomat.com/2015/11/with-trilateral-summit-china-japan-korea-cooperation-completely-restored/

Trilateral meetings involve cooperation between various countries, whereas bilateral meetings should be easier to organize. Trilateral meeting involve a go-between. Neither Japan nor China will act in this way through patriotic pride. It's very unlikely that Korea will do so.

Further to ed3 and agent23421 posts that the meeting has happened but with Prime Minister Li I am reverting back to my original forecast of 0%, as it is unlilely that a second such meeting would be organised within the timeframe. Teach me to make such a radical divergence form my original estimate.
At this point, this should be firmly at zero. p < 0.5%

A Trialteral talk has already taken place albeit without Xi Jinping. This should satisfy the need for a summit until the end of 2015. (http://www.cnn.com/2015/11/01/asia/china-korea-japan-talks/)
Furthermore, it took President Park Geun-hye about over 2 months to secure this summit. A new summit within two months would be unlikely. 
Currently, the President Xi Jinping has shown more assertiveness in his governing of the country. He has taken a much more autocratic rule in comparison with his predecessor. President Xi Jinping sent Li Keqiang, China's Premier, to the summit in order to maintain his image as a conservative leader.

Meeting happened Nov 1, Li (not Xi), Abe, and Park.  http://thediplomat.com/2015/11/china-holds-bilateral-talks-with-south-korea-japan/  Don't expect another this year. Since this didn't close, my assumption that Li might be an acceptable substitute for Xi is not correct.  So going to 0
No, I do not see China holding discussions at that senior a level.
Li attended.  Leaving a little room for ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
Three heads od states to get together in such a short time? not very likely. Two of them just met, maybe it is a opening, but we need to see.
The leaders are meeting in Seoul now without Xi.
I don't think they will meet before Jamuary 1st. There is allot of tension with the spratly Island an other issues for them to rush into a meeting.
They just met--Abe, Park and oops ... Li, not Xi.  That shows Chinese intention.  So, it is unlikely that the three mentioned in the question will meet by year end ... under the normal circumstance.

The "summit" is happening this weekend, but with only 2 of the three personages named in this question.  The Chinese will be represented by Premier Li Quinang, not Xi Jinping.  Looks like this one will be scored a technical knock-out.  Not much chance of a second gathering with Xi at the table before year-end.

Although this question is technically valid until year-end, it should be closed now since the tri-lateral meeting is occurring with Li, not Xi....some people can just lower their Briar Scores because inevitably there are folks who forget to return to the website whilst keeping a probability greater than zero (aka, the benchmark will never reach zero, even though the spirit of this question has basically already been decided as of today). Seems like a slight loophole.

Oh so close!  It was announced that Abe, Geun-hye and _Chinese Premier Li Keqiang_ would meet on this Sunday (November 1).  On the Chinese side, President Xi Jinping will not be meeting.  Since the question is explicit, I count this meeting as a miss.  Therefore, I could probably lower the probability but I will stick with 5%.
Just plain hard to get three world leaders in a room.

According to this weeks economist Prime Minister Abe will be meeting President Park and a Chinese leader, probably prime Minister Li Keqiang at the end of this month. So while probably the prime Minister it could be the president. Its the Baynan article. So such a meeting is taking place this week, but will President Xi Jinping be there? Hence I am gpoing 50% on this one, for while the Economist thinks that it will probably be the Chinese Prime Minister, the president has been touring the world and may want to be there. Though I dont know if he has an existing engagement on the day of the trilateral meeting.

there is no real reason why these three leader should meet on such short notice, the only possible reason would be to discuss an alignment of interest regarding exchange rates as the economy slumps, but even this will wait to see how the Fed and ECB will act by the end of the year (Fed will not change rates and ECB will increase QE)

bi lateral meetings to go ahead. Chances of tri lateral meeting increasing

climbing down (but holding out some hope).  not getting the leaks i was expecting for about now; really was convinced Park would want Xi at the meeting in exchange for going to WWII event in china in Sept, especially with south korean elections (national assembly) due in April 2016 and China being trade partners of choice.   will watch for another week of two before capitulating.  seems li>xi on this one.

Formation of the TPP with the US maybe a further stumbling block. China could further feel the this could hinder the development of their version of the TPP under Chinese  leadership

“When a trilateral summit involving Japan, China and South Korea takes place, I would like to hold separate talks with (South Korean) President Park Geun Hye and (Chinese) Premier Li Keqiang,” Abe said at a news conference on Sept 25. “Difficult issues exist between neighboring countries, and I think that’s why leaders should have talks.”
I can't see any discussion involving all three, and I doubt Xi Jinping feels the need to be mobbed.

Reuters October 6

Given Chinese and Japanese nationalism, and South Korean animosity toward Japanese WWII statements, it's too soon to expect such a meeting.
update for time, and applying a slight increase.
Meetings of senior diplomats may occur, but not heads of state

I'm confident the three countries will meet before year's end. Though as long as reports keep adding  ".. [or] Chinese Premier Li Keqiang" as the rep from China, I'm predicting low that these three specifically attend.
Thought about GJDrew's point, and potential for NK to do something sketchy.

Xi Jingping and Abe are not headed towards peace. Actions on both sides make that impossible. Abe will be supporting the Philippines in concrete ways; Xi will be up to evil on Mischief Reef... Such a meeting impossible.
Hedging a bit on Xi v. Li.  Xi generally appears at everything that's important.  If he feels this is in any way historic, Xi will be there.
There's still confusion on Li v. Xi. http://thediplomat.com/2015/09/abe-park-meet-on-un-sidelines-affirm-trilateral-summit-with-china/
There's still confusion on Li v. Xi. http://thediplomat.com/2015/09/abe-park-meet-on-un-sidelines-affirm-trilateral-summit-with-china/

Just don't feel comfortable super low.  Still differing opinions about who would attend (Xi/Li), and China unlikely to indicate who is going until shortly before the meeting.  Still think Li most likely.

Think it will be Li Keqiang, not Xi.  Seems like massively unnecessary domestic political risk for Xi to see the Japanese given the 70th anniversary hoopla, PLA corruption clean-up and overall tense political environment in Beijing. Xi could be attacked by unfriendly cadres of not being sincere about his antagonism towards Japan, fodder for political enemies. Little upside but significant domestic political downside if Xi goes. Better to let Li Keqiang do it, present a conciliatory gesture to intl community without the domestic political downside of Xi being present. Win win. I see virtually zero upside if Xi goes; why present himself as an equal alongside Abe? It would be insane.

Going from 80 to 20 as I had originally intended.  More sure that meeting will occur but with Li and not Xi based on http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2015/10/01/national/politics-diplomacy/japan-south-korea-vow-ensure-success-three-way-summit-china/#.VgyzgfTcCiw

Even though there is a mutual need to work on various regional issues, it doesn't seem that the three countries have progressed far enough to have a trilateral meeting among the top leaders. It is more apt to be a meeting of representatives. There is little time to put together such a high-level meeting among the top leaders before January 2016.
Moving up a tad; based on some of the comments at UN.

The intent of this question is unclear. Is it asking if a trilateral summit will take place? Or if those three people will be in attendance? China typically sends its premier to these things, not its president. I think that a summit will take place, but I'm unsure if President Xi will be there. President Park has publicly expressed her desire that he attend, and the two of them seem to have developed a rapport. So he does have reason to break with tradition and represent China himself.

Decreasing on basis of passage of time.
Tensions between Abe and the other two leaders have been too high. There have not been much efforts to reduce the tension, and Jan 1 2016 is too close a date for things to change.

The question says "a meeting" - not that they must talk to each other (just kidding!!!! and that was not a trilateral meeting anyway)

Extremely unlikely, especially given flux in Japan Diet and problems between Park and Abe.
I am increasing based on the VOA article.

Abe and Park met at UN.  "At their meeting in New York the leaders of South Korea and Japan reportedly discussed attending the upcoming trilateral summit with Chinese President Xi Jinping, which is being planned for late October or early November." VoA.  That said, most other outlets report Li and not Xi will attend.  Still betting on Xi attending: this based primarily on Parks many comments dating back years that she will want Xi at the meeting;  and he will honour that based on her moves in last few months.  Xi may also think some mileage in him attending as part of his moves in that area.

China does not like to talk when it can show its power and might.
China is more like a bully would rather show what it can do than have diplomatic relations
Not enough time, rising tensions, no sign of lower level work to make it happen. Going to 0%
Highly unlikely that relations will improve in such a short time period, especially given a surge in Japanese nationalism
Unless there is a tremendous amount of backchannel work going on, which would be unusual for this sort of event, there isn't time to put this show on the road before Spring.
It looks like China will be represented at the trilateral meeting they're scheduling by Li Keqiang.
It looks like China will be represented at the trilateral meeting they're scheduling by Li Keqiang.

Media reports suggest this summit is likely sometime around Halloween. It remains unclear whether or not Xi Jinping will be representing China, as China has historically been represented at these trilateral summits by its Prime Minister (Li Keqiang). If Xi ends up attending, it would represent an upgrade of the dialogue.

First, there appears to be no reason for a meeting within such a short time frame.  If this were a routine meeting, it would be a very big event.  There would also be diplomatic preparations and these preparations would be public.  I can't find any.
There is too much tension between China and Japan to allow for a meeting.

Softening stances on the part of the 3 nations towards each other. Abe and Xi have met twice already. Abe's comment regarding the WWII comfort women may be enough for Park to move toward a trilateral meeting, and she is meeting with Xi in Beijing soon.

I'm moving towards the crowd, but not all the way because I think that if DPRK does a nuke test or launches a missile that could radically change things and Xi may decide to participate rather than Li.
Regional tensions,  Jinping is going to Washington, but he also sent an armada to the Aleutians
Belatedly joining others in Li > Xi.
Belatedly joining others in Li > Xi.
Not going to happen. Presidnet Xi is now in Seattle. Headed to Washington, D.C., No talk of trilateral meeting.

With the recent push for a Japan that can project a military presence abroad, I see no reason that China will be friendly with them. I hear the drum beat of war...., not the lull of peace and cooperation.

Will the talks take place? Very probably. (85%)
http://thediplomat.com/2015/09/china-japan-south-korea-to-hold-long-delayed-trilateral-summit/
http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2015/09/16/national/politics-diplomacy/japan-china-south-korea-hold-talks-trilateral-summit/#.VgFhX3tPbdS
But will they take place with all three of the leaders who are specified in the question? Not likely. Park almost certainly since SK holds the trilateral chair; Xi doubtful since China usually sends a representative to these things; Abe 50/50. The easiest way to both hold the meeting and rebuke Japan for its recent vote for military expansion is to publicly call for Abe to stay home. If Japan's rep is the lowest ranking guy in the room, everybody's could save face.
China prefers to divide and conquer.
No, not as the question is stated. There will be a trilateral meeting before 2016, but China will send Prime Minister Li Keqiang instead of president Xi Jinping.
I'm lowering my forecast to be closer to the crowd.  I don't quite understand why crowd sentiment has changed so much; there don't seem to have been any major external events affecting this question.

This meeting will not take place by January 2016 there is too much focus on China and the ADIZ island build up strategy for ASEAN countries and Japan for a meeting to take place soon.

  Japan passes controversial laws expanding possible military roles abroad.  Already negative feed back from SK and China.
People are always talking about this, but it never happens. I think the talk about it this year is exactly like the talk about in in previous years. They may meet, but not in the next 3 months.
Unless a Change in acting persons occurs (Japan or China), not Relaxation is to be expected.
Posturing is so important in these cultures that this may never take place.  So many benefits for all though, should it take place.
Sounds promising that this could happen in the near future.  http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2015/09/16/national/politics-diplomacy/japan-china-south-korea-hold-talks-trilateral-summit/#.VfxyyZcWJSM

A meeting now is to the benefit of all three leaders, domestically and internationally.  China, in particular, needs a forum in which to appear reasonable and responsible, which may help their economy.

Pushed the wrong button. There is always a chance, but 5% seems more plausible.

There seems to be little time to organize such a thing. Barring some extraordinary event to spur action, I think that the likelihood is low (but non-zero).
Li meeting soon with Park and Abe soon. Not Xi.

I have not found an article from China confirming whether Xi Jinping or Li Keqiang will attend (just from Japan) but there are good reasons for Xi to go. China is making efforts to strengthen its relationship with South Korea.  When Park Geun-hye attended China’s WWII parade, she was the only leader of a country allied with the United States to accept the invitation.  She got a front row seat next to Putin who was next to Xi.  Her prominent position was not by mistake.  The last trilateral summit occurred before Xi became president. In the past the Chinese president has not attended, but Xi may not feel bound by how past summits have been handled, especially when his attendance can make a statement to the United States and North Korea.  China’s relationship with the United States is more contentious now than it was in 2012.  Also, think of the effect on Kim Jong-un (who has yet to visit China) if Xi chooses to go to South Korea for the summit.  This question is one to watch and my forecast may turn out to be very wrong.  I just do not have the sense that a firm decision has been made for Li to go.

It's pretty low, given the short timeframe, and current unresolved regional issues. China has other priorities at this time. Question specifies that Xi must attend, which is not in keepig with prior attendance.
I think such a meeting is both likely and inevitable, but not by the end of this year, especially considering the soft economic news coming from all three countries.

While South Korea wants closer relationship with China, not only for economic reasons but also to seek better cooperation regarding the North-South issues on the Korean peninsula, the relationship between China and Japan remains frosty over territorial disputes, economic issues, Japan's perceived military threat from China, and the Chinese using Japan as whipping boy to distract from internal political issues. The probability of a trilateral meeting for the leaders of these 3 countries remains low.

China and South Korea have agreed to invite Abe to a meeting before year end.  China is tilting towards South Korea and away from North Korea.  This could be an indication that China has become uncomfortable with a nuclear-capable North Korea and maybe sees more commercial advantages to a parternship with the South, now that it's economy is down.  So I'm switching my vote to more like Yes than No.  This depends on Japan of course.  However I can imagine that the US would encourage Japan to participate.

From previous reports, a trilateral summit of some kind seems likely by the end of 2015; I'll give it 70% odds.  However, there seem to be mixed signals as to whether Xi Jinping or Li Keqiang will attend; media reports vaguely suggest Xi, while previous history suggests Li.  I think they are about equally likely to attend, so I am halving my odds.

The article noted below is crucial in this proposition.  http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20150902001200
Other articles are popping up that state the summit would be between the three leaders and not just ministers.  
Notably this one about four hours ago:  http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20150902001234
I was skeptical for a meeting in four months with no solid announcement.  But per the aforementioned articles, Korea and China state their intentions to meet in Japan in October or November, and other articles support.  Therefore, I believe that we have a defacto announcement of a meeting before year-end, which is one of the things that would entirely change my mind on this proposition.  So just one day after my first prediction, I am totally reversing!  Oh well, when I get new facts...I make new conclusions.

Abe has aggravated all his neighbors with his visits to Yasukuni & mealy-mouthed acknowledgement of Japan's WWII war crimes.  Unless Kim does something that requires a unified regional response, I don't see this happening in the next 3 months.
